perturbation.changed_text: (c)  "Contract Territory" shall mean the Continental United States.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract defines the 'Contract Territory' as the entire world. By changing this to 'Continental United States', the contract now limits the geographical scope of the agreement. This may contradict international business laws if TPC intends to exploit Ogle's endorsement globally, introducing a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: International Business Law, specific to endorsement rights and geographical limitations.

perturbation.original_text: 27. EMPLOYER/EMPLOYEE RELATIONSHIP. Nothing contained in this Agreement shall be construed as establishing an employer/employee relationship between TPC and Consolidated Artists. Accordingly, there shall be no withholding for tax purposes from any payments due hereunder to Consolidated Artists by TPC.
perturbation.changed_text: 27. EMPLOYER/EMPLOYEE RELATIONSHIP. Nothing contained in this Agreement shall automatically be construed as establishing an employer/employee relationship between TPC and Consolidated Artists. However, should Consolidated Artists perform duties typically associated with an employee, such as direct supervision by TPC, this may retroactively be considered an employer/employee relationship. Tax withholding shall be determined at the sole discretion of TPC.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause explicitly states that no employer/employee relationship exists. The modification introduces ambiguity by suggesting that such a relationship could arise based on actions, contradicting the initial statement. Furthermore, stating that 'Tax withholding shall be determined at the sole discretion of TPC' contradicts IRS regulations which dictate the criteria and requirements for employee vs. independent contractor classification and associated tax obligations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS Tax Regulations on Employee vs. Independent Contractor classification.

perturbation.original_text: 16. TIME OF THE ESSENCE. TPC acknowledges that time is of the essence in the payment of all compensation due Consolidated Artists hereunder. For the purposes of this Agreement, all payments not received within thirty (30) days of the date due shall be deemed "past due". Such past due payments shall bear interest at a rate of two percent (2%) per month OR the maximum rate permissible by law, whichever is less. The imposition of interest provided for in this Paragraph shall be in addition to any other remedies available to Consolidated Artists under this Agreement or otherwise. Accordingly, Consolidated Artists shall not be precluded from exercising any other remedies, whether at law or in equity, to enforce the terms of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: 16. TIME OF THE ESSENCE. TPC acknowledges that time may be of the essence in the payment of all compensation due Consolidated Artists hereunder, dependent on TPC's cash flow. For the purposes of this Agreement, all payments not received within ninety (90) days of the date due may be deemed "past due" at Consolidated Artist's discretion. Such past due payments shall bear interest, but only if explicitly agreed upon separately. The imposition of interest is the sole remedy available to Consolidated Artists under this Agreement or otherwise. Accordingly, Consolidated Artists shall be precluded from exercising any other remedies, whether at law or in equity, to enforce the terms of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause clearly establishes 'time is of the essence' for payments, defines 'past due,' sets an interest rate for late payments, and allows for all available legal remedies. The modified text weakens the 'time is of the essence' clause, changes the 'past due' timeframe to 90 days, makes interest discretionary, and restricts Consolidated Artists' remedies solely to interest. This weakens payment enforcement and conflicts with standard contract law principles regarding available remedies for breach of contract under Virginia law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Breach of Contract Remedies, Virginia State Law.
